title: Front Wheel - Installation

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle Including locking devices
Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Note to be used in service manual with stabilise warning
Renew locking devices where specified, refer to
Before tightening a fixing using a crow foot spanner adapter, refer to
Use of Crow Foot Spanner Adapters with Torque Wrenches
Observe all torque wrench tightening procedures, refer to
The tyre is marked with a direction of rotation arrow during manufacture.
Make sure the tyre is fitted with it's direction arrow matching the direction of rotation arrow on the wheel.
An incorrectly fitted tyre will result in a dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control which could result in serious injury or death.
Make sure the tyre is fitted with its rotation arrow facing the same way as the rotation arrow on the front wheel.
Lightly smear the wheel spacers with grease and locate in the hubs.
The wheel is marked with a direction of rotation arrow during manufacture.
The wheel must be fitted with the direction arrows corresponding to the wheel rotation of the motorcycle when travelling in a forward direction.
An incorrectly fitted wheel will result in a dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control which could result in serious injury or death.

Position the wheel between the forks making sure the brake disc is fitted to the left hand side, the direction of rotation arrow corresponds to the wheel rotation and the spacers are located in position on both sides of the wheel.
Fit the wheel spindle from the right hand side and tighten to
Lower the motorcycle to the ground and position the front wheel up against a fixed surface.
Bounce the front suspension numerous times to allow the right hand fork to float to its natural position on the wheel spindle.
Do not lean on the motorcycle or compress the front suspension whilst tightening the fork pinch bolts.
Tighten the fork pinch bolts in the following sequence:
Retighten the outer fork pinch bolt to
Thoroughly clean and degrease the brake disc.
Thoroughly clean the threaded fixing holes for the brake caliper fixings.
Position the brake caliper over the disc.

Secure the brake caliper with the new fixings and tighten sufficiently to bring the caliper into contact with its mounting points, while allowing a small amount of lateral movement. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Visually check the clearance between caliper body and the brake disc as described in
To centralise the front brake caliper
Operate the front brake lever to make sure the brake pads are positioned against the brake disc.
Do not allow the wheel to rotate
With the aid of an assistant, hold sufficient pressure to the brake lever to keep the brake pads in contact with the brake disc.
Secure the brake caliper in the following sequence:
Fit the ABS wheel speed sensor and tighten it's fixing to
Route the ABS sensor cable and secure with the clip as shown below.

body.name: Caliper to front fork for wheel removal_TP0173_1

body.body: Rotate the front wheel and check the clearance between the brake caliper body and the front brake disc.
It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes.
Take remedial action before you ride the motorcycle again.
Failure to take remedial action may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Check the operation of the front brake. Rectify as necessary.

Lower the motorcycle to the ground and position the front wheel up against a fixed surface.
Bounce the front suspension numerous times to allow the right hand fork to float to its natural position on the wheel spindle.
Do not lean on the motorcycle or compress the front suspension whilst tightening the fork pinch bolts.

Thoroughly clean and degrease the brake disc.
Thoroughly clean the threaded fixing holes for the brake caliper fixings.
Position the brake caliper over the disc.

Secure the brake caliper with the new fixings and tighten sufficiently to bring the caliper into contact with its mounting points, while allowing a small amount of lateral movement. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Visually check the clearance between caliper body and the brake disc as described in
Front Brake Caliper - Installation
To centralise the front brake caliper
Operate the front brake lever to make sure the brake pads are positioned against the brake disc.
Do not allow the wheel to rotate
With the aid of an assistant, hold sufficient pressure to the brake lever to keep the brake pads in contact with the brake disc.
Secure the brake caliper in the following sequence:

Upper fixing to

Lower fixing to
15 Nm

Upper fixing to

Fit the ABS wheel speed sensor and tighten it's fixing to

Route the ABS sensor cable and secure with the clip as shown below.

Rotate the front wheel and check the clearance between the brake caliper body and the front brake disc.
It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes.
Take remedial action before you ride the motorcycle again.
Failure to take remedial action may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Check the operation of the front brake. Rectify as necessary.
